article:
Murdaugh Family

The Murdaugh family is a prominent family in the Lowcountry region of South Carolina, USA. They have been involved in the legal profession for several generations, with a number of notable members practicing law in the state. However, in recent years, the family has been embroiled in various controversies, including murders, embezzlement, and narcotics distribution charges.

#14th District

The 14th Circuit Solicitor's Office, which covers Beaufort, Jasper, Hampton, Colleton, and Allendale counties in South Carolina, has been led by members of the Murdaugh family for nearly a century. The office is responsible for prosecuting crimes in the five-county region. The Murdaughs' involvement in the office dates back to 1920, when Randolph Murdaugh Sr. was first elected as solicitor.

#Family Law Firm

The Murdaugh family has also operated a private law firm, Peters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth, and Detrick, P.A. (PMPED), which was founded by Randolph Murdaugh Sr. in 1910. The firm, which has offices in Hampton and Beaufort, specializes in personal injury, medical malpractice, and wrongful death cases. Several members of the Murdaugh family have worked at the firm over the years, including Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr., Randolph Murdaugh III, and Alex Murdaugh.

#Murdaugh Hunting Estate

The Murdaugh family has a long-standing tradition of hunting and outdoor activities. They own a large hunting estate in Colleton County, which has been the site of various hunting trips and social gatherings over the years. The estate has also been the scene of several controversies, including the death of a young woman, Mallory Beach, who was killed in a boating accident in 2019.

#Notable Members

##Randolph Murdaugh Sr.

Randolph Murdaugh Sr. was a lawyer and politician who served as the solicitor for the 14th Circuit from 1920 until his death in 1940. He was the founder of the family law firm, PMPED, and was known for his aggressive prosecution style.

##Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr.

Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. was a lawyer and politician who served as the solicitor for the 14th Circuit from 1940 until his death in 1998. He was the son of Randolph Murdaugh Sr. and continued the family's tradition of prosecuting crimes in the region.

##Randolph Murdaugh III

Randolph Murdaugh III is a lawyer who has worked at the family law firm, PMPED. He is the son of Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. and has been involved in various high-profile cases over the years.

##Alex Murdaugh

Alex Murdaugh is a lawyer who has worked at the family law firm, PMPED. He is the son of Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. and has been involved in various controversies, including the murders of his wife and son.

##Maggie Murdaugh

Maggie Murdaugh was the wife of Alex Murdaugh and the mother of their two sons, Buster and Paul. She was killed in 2021, along with her son Paul, in a shooting at the family's hunting estate.

##Buster Murdaugh

Buster Murdaugh is the son of Alex and Maggie Murdaugh. He has been involved in various controversies, including a drunken driving incident in 2019.

##Paul Murdaugh

Paul Murdaugh was the son of Alex and Maggie Murdaugh. He was killed in 2021, along with his mother, in a shooting at the family's hunting estate.

#Alex Murdaugh Murders and Other Legal Issues

The Murdaugh family has been embroiled in various controversies in recent years, including the murders of Maggie and Paul Murdaugh. The investigation into their deaths is ongoing, and several other legal issues have arisen in connection with the case.

##Ongoing Investigations and Legal Actions

###Murder of Stephen Smith

Stephen Smith was a young man who was killed in a hit-and-run accident in 2015. The case was initially investigated by the South Carolina Highway Patrol, but it was later taken over by the 14th Circuit Solicitor's Office, which was led by Alex Murdaugh at the time. The investigation into Smith's death is ongoing, and several members of the Murdaugh family have been questioned in connection with the case.

###Death of Gloria Satterfield

Gloria Satterfield was a housekeeper who worked for the Murdaugh family. She died in 2018 after falling down the stairs at the family's home. The investigation into her death was initially handled by the 14th Circuit Solicitor's Office, but it was later taken over by the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED).

###Death of Mallory Beach

Mallory Beach was a young woman who was killed in a boating accident in 2019. The accident occurred at the Murdaugh family's hunting estate, and several members of the family were on board the boat at the time of the accident. The investigation into Beach's death is ongoing, and several members of the Murdaugh family have been questioned in connection with the case.

###Assisted Suicide Fraud

Alex Murdaugh has been accused of assisting in the suicide of a man who was terminally ill. The man's family has filed a lawsuit against Murdaugh, alleging that he helped the man to end his life in exchange for a large sum of money.

###Embezzlement

Alex Murdaugh has been accused of embezzling money from his law firm, PMPED. The firm has filed a lawsuit against Murdaugh, alleging that he took hundreds of thousands of dollars from the firm's accounts without permission.

###Charges for Narcotics Distribution

Alex Murdaugh has been charged with narcotics distribution in connection with the death of a man who overdosed on opioids. The investigation into the case is ongoing, and several other members of the Murdaugh family have been questioned in connection with the case.

###Lindsey Edwards Allegations

Lindsey Edwards, a woman who has been romantically linked to Alex Murdaugh, has filed a lawsuit against him, alleging that he took advantage of her and used her for his own gain. The lawsuit also alleges that Murdaugh was involved in the death of a man who was murdered in 2015.

###Forge Consulting Lawsuit

Forge Consulting, a company that provided consulting services to the Murdaugh family, has filed a lawsuit against Alex Murdaugh, alleging that he failed to pay the company for its services.

###Santis-Cristiani Lawsuit

Santis-Cristiani, a company that provided security services to the Murdaugh family, has filed a lawsuit against Alex Murdaugh, alleging that he failed to pay the company for its services.

###Criminal Tax Evasion

Alex Murdaugh has been charged with criminal tax evasion in connection with his failure to pay taxes on income he earned from his law practice. The investigation into the case is ongoing, and several other members of the Murdaugh family have been questioned in connection with the case.

##Convictions, Civil Judgments, Settlements, and Sanctions

Alex Murdaugh has been convicted of the murders of his wife, Maggie, and their son, Paul. He is currently facing life in prison without the possibility of parole.

###Fraud and Money Laundering Charges

####State Indictments

Alex Murdaugh has been indicted on state charges of fraud and money laundering in connection with his alleged embezzlement of money from his law firm, PMPED.

####Federal Indictment 22 Counts

Alex Murdaugh has been indicted on federal charges of fraud and money laundering in connection with his alleged embezzlement of money from his law firm, PMPED. article:
2023 in Philippine television

The year 2023 in Philippine television marked a significant period of changes and developments in the industry. This article provides an overview of the major events, debuts, returning or renamed programs, and finales that took place in the Philippine television landscape in 2023.

# Events

## January

* January 1: GMA Network, one of the major television networks in the Philippines, launched its new slogan "Love Shines" to kick off the new year.
* January 15: TV5, another major network, premiered its new primetime drama series "Walang Matigas na Pulis sa Matinik na Misis" starring Robin Padilla and Jodi Sta. Maria.

## February

* February 1: A2Z, a joint venture between ABS-CBN Corporation and Zoe Broadcasting Network, launched its new morning show "A2Z Morning" hosted by Karen Davila and Julius Babao.
* February 14: GMA Network aired a special Valentine's Day episode of its popular drama series "First Yaya" starring Sanya Lopez and Gabby Concepcion.

## March

* March 1: PTV, the flagship television network of the Philippine government, launched its new news program "PTV News Tonight" anchored by Rocky Ignacio and Karlo Nograles.
* March 20: TV5 premiered its new reality show "The Clash" hosted by Billy Crawford and Julie Anne San Jose.

## April

* April 1: GMA Network launched its new afternoon drama series "Nakarehas na Puso" starring Sunshine Dizon and Benjamin Alves.
* April 17: A2Z premiered its new primetime drama series "The Fake Life" starring Xian Lim and Kylie Padilla.

## May

* May 1: TV5 launched its new morning show "Good Morning Kapatid" hosted by MJ Marfori and Macoy Dubs.
* May 15: PTV aired a special episode of its documentary series "PTV Documentaries" featuring the life and legacy of the late President Corazon Aquino.

## June

* June 1: GMA Network premiered its new primetime drama series "Love. Die. Repeat" starring Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards.
* June 19: A2Z launched its new reality show "The Great Filipino Cook-Off" hosted by Boy Abunda and Nancy Lumen.

## July

* July 1: TV5 launched its new afternoon drama series "Sahaya, Ang Pinagmulan" starring Snooky Serna and Sunshine Cruz.
* July 17: PTV aired a special episode of its news program "PTV News Tonight" featuring an exclusive interview with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.

## August

* August 1: GMA Network premiered its new morning show "GMA Morning" hosted by Arnold Clavio and Connie Sison.
* August 21: A2Z launched its new primetime drama series "Magandang Dilag" starring Janine Gutierrez and Zanjoe Marudo.

## September

* September 1: TV5 launched its new reality show "The Amazing Race Philippines" hosted by Derek Ramsay.
* September 18: PTV aired a special episode of its documentary series "PTV Documentaries" featuring the life and legacy of the late President Fidel Ramos.

## October

* October 1: GMA Network premiered its new afternoon drama series "Kahit Maputi na ang Buhok Ko" starring Snooky Serna and Tirso Cruz III.
* October 16: A2Z launched its new morning show "A2Z Morning News" hosted by Julius Babao and Karen Davila.

## November

* November 1: TV5 launched its new primetime drama series " FPJ's Ang Probinsyano" starring Coco Martin.
* November 20: PTV aired a special episode of its news program "PTV News Tonight" featuring an exclusive interview with Vice President Sara Duterte.

## December

* December 1: GMA Network premiered its new reality show "The Voice Kids Philippines" hosted by Toni Gonzaga and Robi Domingo.
* December 25: A2Z aired a special Christmas episode of its primetime drama series "Magandang Dilag" starring Janine Gutierrez and Zanjoe Marudo.

article:
2023 India Open (badminton)

The 2023 India Open was a badminton tournament that took place at the K. D. Jadhav Indoor Hall in New Delhi, India, from January 17 to 22, 2023. It was the 11th edition of the India Open and a part of the 2023 BWF World Tour.

# Tournament

## Venue

The tournament was held at the K. D. Jadhav Indoor Hall in New Delhi, India. The venue has a seating capacity of 5,000 and is one of the premier badminton stadiums in India.

## Point distribution

The tournament offered points towards the 2023 BWF World Tour, with the winner of each discipline earning 12,000 points. The point distribution was as follows:

* Winner: 12,000 points
* Runner-up: 10,200 points
* Semi-finalist: 8,400 points
* Quarter-finalist: 6,600 points
* Last 16: 4,800 points
* Last 32: 3,000 points
* Last 64: 1,200 points

## Prize money

The total prize money for the tournament was $900,000, with the winner of each discipline earning $67,500.

# Men's singles

## Seeds

The top eight seeds for the men's singles discipline were:

1. Viktor Axelson (Denmark)
2. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
3. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
4. Kento Momota (Japan)
5. Jonatan Christie (Indonesia)
6. Anthony Ginting (Indonesia)
7. Loh Kean Yew (Singapore)

2023 Badminton Asia Championships

The 2023 Badminton Asia Championships is a continental badminton tournament that took place in Dubai, United Arab Emirates from April 25 to April 30, 2023. The championships were organized by the Badminton Asia Confederation and featured the top badminton players from Asia competing in five events: men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles.

# Tournament

## Venue

The 2023 Badminton Asia Championships were held at the Dubai Exhibition Centre in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. The venue featured multiple courts and state-of-the-art facilities, providing an ideal setting for the top badminton players in Asia to compete.

## Point distribution

The tournament followed the standard point distribution system used in badminton tournaments. Players earned points based on their performance in each match, with the winner earning the most points. The points were distributed as follows:

* Winner: 7,000 points
* Runner-up: 5,950 points
* Semi-finalist: 4,580 points
* Quarter-finalist: 3,430 points
* Last 16: 2,150 points

article:
2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup Global Qualifier A

The 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup Global Qualifier A was a cricket tournament that took place in February 2022 in Oman and the United Arab Emirates. The tournament was one of two global qualifiers for the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup, with the top two teams from each qualifier advancing to the tournament in Australia.

The tournament featured eight teams, with the United Arab Emirates and Ireland entering as the top seeds. The other teams that participated in the tournament were Bahrain, Canada, Germany, the Philippines, and Uganda. The teams were divided into two groups, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the play-offs.

#Squads

article:
Giorgio Napolitano

Giorgio Napolitano is an Italian politician who served as the 11th President of Italy from 2006 to 2015. He is the longest-serving President in Italian history and the first to be elected for a second term. Napolitano's presidency was marked by significant events, including the 2008 financial crisis, the European sovereign-debt crisis, and the rise of the Five Star Movement. Throughout his career, Napolitano has been a prominent figure in Italian politics, known for his commitment to social democracy and his efforts to promote European integration.

# Early life

Giorgio Napolitano was born on June 29, 1925, in Naples, Italy. He came from a middle-class family and grew up in a culturally rich environment. Napolitano's parents were both educated and valued knowledge, encouraging their son to pursue his academic interests. He attended the Liceo Classico Giambattista Vico in Naples, where he developed a passion for classical studies and literature. After completing his secondary education, Napolitano enrolled in the University of Naples, where he studied law.

# Early political career

## World War II and anti-fascist resistance

During World War II, Napolitano became involved in the anti-fascist resistance movement. In 1942, he joined the Italian Socialist Party, which was part of the underground resistance against the fascist regime. Napolitano's involvement in the resistance movement exposed him to the harsh realities of war and shaped his political views. After the war, he continued his studies, eventually earning a degree in law from the University of Naples.

## From post-war years to the Hungarian Revolution of 1956

In the post-war years, Napolitano became increasingly involved in politics. He joined the Italian Communist Party (PCI) in 1945 and quickly rose through the ranks. Napolitano's early political career was marked by his involvement in the PCI's youth organization, the Italian Communist Youth Federation. He also served as a member of the PCI's central committee, where he played a key role in shaping the party's policies. The Hungarian Revolution of 1956 marked a significant turning point in Napolitano's career. He was part of a delegation that visited Hungary, where he witnessed the brutal suppression of the uprising. This experience had a profound impact on Napolitano, leading him to re-evaluate his views on communism and the role of the PCI in Italian politics.

# Leading member of the Italian Communist Party

## From the 1960s to 1980s

In the 1960s, Napolitano emerged as a leading figure in the PCI. He served as a member of the Italian Parliament, representing the PCI in the Chamber of Deputies. During this period, Napolitano played a key role in shaping the PCI's policies, particularly with regard to foreign policy and European integration. He was a strong advocate for Italy's membership in the European Economic Community (EEC) and played a key role in negotiating Italy's accession to the EEC in 1957. Napolitano's leadership within the PCI was marked by his efforts to promote a more liberal and democratic approach to communism. He was part of a faction within the party that sought to reform the PCI and make it more responsive to the needs of the Italian people.

# After the Italian Communist Party

## President of the Chamber of Deputies

In 1992, Napolitano was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies, a position he held until 1994. During his presidency, he played a key role in promoting reforms to the Italian electoral system and in strengthening the role of the parliament in Italian politics.

## Late 1990s and early 2000s

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Napolitano continued to play an active role in Italian politics. He served as a member of the Italian Senate and was a key figure in the Democratic Left party, which was formed in 1998. Napolitano's leadership within the party was marked by his efforts to promote a more liberal and social democratic approach to politics.

# President of Italy

## First term (2006–2013)

### Election

Napolitano was elected President of Italy on May 10, 2006, receiving 543 votes in the fourth round of voting. His election was seen as a significant victory for the center-left coalition, which had been in opposition for several years.

### Prodi Cabinet

During his first term, Napolitano played a key role in promoting stability and continuity in Italian politics. He worked closely with Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who formed a center-left government in 2006. Napolitano's relationship with Prodi was marked by a deep respect for the prime minister's efforts to promote economic reform and European integration.

### 2008 political crisis

In 2008, Napolitano faced a significant challenge when the Prodi government was defeated in a confidence vote. Napolitano played a key role in promoting a peaceful transition of power, working closely with the leaders of the center-right coalition to form a new government.

### Eluana Englaro incident

In 2009, Napolitano was involved in a highly publicized incident surrounding the case of Eluana Englaro, a young woman who had been in a coma for 17 years. Napolitano's decision to sign a decree allowing Englaro's feeding tube to be removed was seen as a significant challenge to the authority of the Italian parliament.

### 2011 political crisis

In 2011, Napolitano faced another significant challenge when the Berlusconi government was defeated in a confidence vote. Napolitano played a key role in promoting a peaceful transition of power, working closely with the leaders of the center-left coalition to form a new government.

## Second term (2013–2015)

### Re-election

Napolitano was re-elected President of Italy on April 20, 2013, receiving 738 votes in the sixth round of voting. His re-election was seen as a significant victory for the center-left coalition, which had been in opposition for several years.

### Letta Cabinet

During his second term, Napolitano worked closely with Prime Minister Enrico Letta, who formed a center-left government in 2013. Napolitano's relationship with Letta was marked by a deep respect for the prime minister's efforts to promote economic reform and European integration.

### Renzi Cabinet

In 2014, Napolitano worked closely with Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, who formed a center-left government. Napolitano's relationship with Renzi was marked by a deep respect for the prime minister's efforts to promote economic reform and European integration.

## Resignation

Napolitano resigned as President of Italy on January 14, 2015, citing his advanced age and declining health.

## Later life

After his resignation, Napolitano returned to private life. He has continued to play an active role in Italian politics, serving as a senator for life.

# Personal life

## Relations with the Catholic Church

Napolitano has had a complex relationship with the Catholic Church throughout his career. While he has been critical of the Church's role in Italian politics, he has also sought to promote greater understanding and cooperation between the Church and the state.

## Death and state funeral

Napolitano died on September 22, 2023, at the age of 98. He was given a state funeral, which was attended by dignitaries from across Italy and Europe.

# Legacy

Napolitano's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered as a champion of social democracy and European integration, and his efforts to promote stability and continuity in Italian politics have been widely praised. However, his presidency was also marked by significant challenges, including the 2008 financial crisis and the European sovereign-debt crisis.

article:
2022 in Philippine Television

The year 2022 in Philippine television was marked by significant events, new programs, and changes in the television landscape. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the major developments that took place in the Philippine television industry during 2022.

# Events

## January

* January 1: GMA Network launched its new slogan "Buong Puso Para sa Pilipino" (Wholehearted for the Filipino).
* January 3: TV5's news program "Frontline Pilipinas" premiered, replacing "Aksyon Prime".
* January 10: ABS-CBN's drama series "Viral Scandal" premiered, starring Jake Cuenca and Dimples Romana.

## February

* February 1: GMA Network's romantic comedy series "Artikulo 247" premiered, starring Rhian Ramos and Kris Bernal.
* February 7: TV5's game show "Sing Galing!" premiered, hosted by Joey de Leon and It's Showtime's Vice Ganda.
* February 14: A2Z's drama series "Babawiin Ko ang Lahat" premiered, starring Carmina Villaroel and John Estrada.

## March

* March 1: GMA Network's drama series "Raising Mamay" premiered, starring Jean Garcia and Althea Ablan.
* March 7: TV5's news program "Manghuhula" premiered, hosted by Korina Sanchez-Roxas.
* March 14: ABS-CBN's drama series "2 Good 2 Be True" premiered, starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla.

## April

* April 1: GMA Network's fantasy drama series "Agimat ng Agila" premiered, starring Bong Revilla and Sanya Lopez.
* April 4: TV5's game show "PBA on TV5" premiered, featuring the Philippine Basketball Association.
* April 11: A2Z's drama series "The Broken Marriage Vow" premiered, starring Jodi Sta. Maria and Zanjoe Marudo.

## May

* May 1: GMA Network's drama series "First Lady" premiered, starring Sanya Lopez and Gabby Concepcion.
* May 2: TV5's news program "Frontline sa Umaga" premiered, replacing "Frontline Pilipinas".
* May 9: ABS-CBN's drama series "Love in 40 Days" premiered, starring Janine Gutierrez and Paulo Avelino.

## June

* June 1: GMA Network's romantic comedy series "What We Could Be" premiered, starring Andrea Torres and Christian Bables.
* June 6: TV5's game show "Sing Galing! Season 2" premiered, hosted by Joey de Leon and It's Showtime's Vice Ganda.
* June 13: A2Z's drama series "The Fake Life" premiered, starring Jaclyn Jose and Andrea del Rosario.

## July

* July 1: GMA Network's drama series " TiktoClock" premiered, starring Kyline Alcantara and Joaquin Domagoso.
* July 4: TV5's news program "Manghuhula sa Gabi" premiered, hosted by Korina Sanchez-Roxas.
* July 11: ABS-CBN's drama series "The Iron Heart" premiered, starring Richard Gutierrez and Louise delos Reyes.

## August

* August 1: GMA Network's drama series "Beautiful Justice" premiered, starring Yasmien Kurdi and Bea Binene.
* August 8: TV5's game show "PBA on TV5 Season 2" premiered, featuring the Philippine Basketball Association.

## September

* September 1: GMA Network's romantic comedy series "Unica Hija" premiered, starring Marian Rivera and Jestoni Alarcon.
* September 5: TV5's news program "Frontline sa Umaga Season 2" premiered, replacing "Frontline sa Umaga".
* September 12: ABS-CBN's drama series "A Family Affair" premiered, starring Ivana Alawi and Gerald Anderson.

## October

* October 1: GMA Network's drama series "Abot-Kamay na Pangarap" premiered, starring Carmina Villaroel and Jillian Ward.
* October 3: TV5's game show "Sing Galing! Season 3" premiered, hosted by Joey de Leon and It's Showtime's Vice Ganda.
* October 10: A2Z's drama series "Pira-Pirasong Paraiso" premiered, starring Pokwang and Jayson Gainza.

## November

* November 1: GMA Network's drama series "Maria Clara at Ibarra" premiered, starring Barbie Forteza and David Licauco.
* November 7: TV5's news program "Manghuhula sa Gabi Season 2" premiered, hosted by Korina Sanchez-Roxas.
* November 14: ABS-CBN's drama series "Dirty Linen" premiered, starring Janine Gutierrez and Paulo Avelino.

## December

* December 1: GMA Network's romantic comedy series "The Gifted Graduates" premiered, starring Ysabel Ortega and Jeric Gonzales.
* December 5: TV5's game show "PBA on TV5 Season 3" premiered, featuring the Philippine Basketball Association.

article:
Judiciary of Poland

The judiciary of Poland is the system of courts and tribunals responsible for the administration of justice in Poland. It is an independent branch of the Polish government, alongside the legislative and executive branches. The judiciary is composed of various types of courts and tribunals, including common courts, military courts, the Supreme Court, administrative courts, the Constitutional Tribunal, and the State Tribunal. The judiciary plays a crucial role in upholding the rule of law, protecting human rights, and ensuring the fair and impartial administration of justice in Poland.

# Structure

## Common courts

Common courts in Poland are the primary courts of general jurisdiction, responsible for hearing civil, criminal, and family cases. They are divided into two tiers: district courts (sądy rejonowe) and regional courts (sądy okręgowe). District courts are the first-instance courts, hearing cases involving less serious crimes and smaller civil claims. Regional courts, on the other hand, hear appeals from district courts and cases involving more serious crimes and larger civil claims.

## Military courts

Military courts in Poland are specialized courts responsible for hearing cases involving members of the Polish Armed Forces and other military personnel. They are divided into two tiers: military district courts (sądy wojskowe garnizonowe) and the High Military Court (Sąd Wojskowy Najwyższy). Military courts have jurisdiction over crimes committed by military personnel, as well as disciplinary cases.

## Supreme Court

The Supreme Court (Sąd Najwyższy) is the highest court of appeal in Poland, responsible for hearing appeals from lower courts and ensuring the uniform application of the law. The Supreme Court has several chambers, each specializing in a particular area of law, such as civil, criminal, and labor law.

## Administrative courts

Administrative courts in Poland are responsible for hearing cases involving administrative decisions and actions taken by government agencies and public officials. They are divided into two tiers: administrative courts (sądy administracyjne) and the Supreme Administrative Court (Naczelny Sąd Administracyjny). Administrative courts have jurisdiction over cases involving administrative decisions, such as those related to taxation, social security, and environmental protection.

## Constitutional Tribunal

The Constitutional Tribunal (Trybunał Konstytucyjny) is a specialized court responsible for ensuring that laws and government actions are consistent with the Constitution of Poland. The Constitutional Tribunal has the power to strike down laws and government actions that are deemed unconstitutional.

## State Tribunal

The State Tribunal (Trybunał Stanu) is a court responsible for hearing cases involving high-ranking government officials, including the President, Prime Minister, and members of the Council of Ministers. The State Tribunal has jurisdiction over cases involving crimes committed by these officials, as well as cases involving impeachment.

# Procedure

The procedure for court proceedings in Poland varies depending on the type of case and the court hearing it. Generally, court proceedings involve the submission of written pleadings, the presentation of evidence, and the oral arguments of the parties involved. Decisions are typically made by a panel of judges, although some cases may be heard by a single judge.

# Staff

## Judges and court assessors

Judges and court assessors in Poland are responsible for hearing cases and making decisions. They are appointed by the National Council of the Judiciary, a body composed of judges, lawyers, and other members of the judiciary.

### National Council of the Judiciary

The National Council of the Judiciary (Krajowa Rada Sądownictwa) is a constitutional body responsible for appointing judges and ensuring the independence of the judiciary. The National Council is composed of 15 members, including judges, lawyers, and other members of the judiciary.

#### Procedure of appointment

The procedure for appointing judges in Poland involves several steps. First, the National Council of the Judiciary advertises for applications from qualified candidates. Candidates must have a law degree and at least 10 years of experience as a lawyer or judge. The National Council then reviews the applications and selects candidates for interview. After the interview, the National Council recommends candidates for appointment to the President, who formally appoints them as judges.

#### Rights and duties

Judges in Poland have several rights and duties. They have the right to independence and impartiality, as well as the right to freedom from external influence. Judges are also required to uphold the Constitution and the law, and to ensure the fair and impartial administration of justice.

## Judges sitting in the tribunals

Judges sitting in the tribunals, including the Constitutional Tribunal and the State Tribunal, are appointed by the National Council of the Judiciary. These judges have specialized expertise in constitutional and administrative law.

## Other judicial positions

In addition to judges, there are several other judicial positions in Poland, including court clerks, court administrators, and bailiffs. These positions are responsible for supporting the work of the courts and ensuring the smooth administration of justice.

## Remuneration

Judges and other judicial staff in Poland are remunerated by the state. Judges are paid a salary, which is set by the National Council of the Judiciary. Other judicial staff, such as court clerks and court administrators, are also paid a salary, which is set by the Ministry of Justice.

# Minimal requirements

To become a judge in Poland, a candidate must meet certain minimal requirements. These include:

* A law degree from a Polish university
* At least 10 years of experience as a lawyer or judge
* A good command of the Polish language
* A clean record of conduct

# Issues

## Length of proceedings

One of the main issues affecting the judiciary in Poland is the length of proceedings. Many court cases take several years to complete, which can cause delays and frustration for parties involved.

## Lack of popular support and trust

Another issue affecting the judiciary in Poland is the lack of popular support and trust. Many Poles have lost confidence in the judiciary, which they see as corrupt and ineffective.

## Other issues

There are several other issues affecting the judiciary in Poland, including:

* Corruption: There have been several high-profile cases of corruption involving judges and other judicial staff.
* Inefficiency: The courts in Poland are often slow and inefficient, leading to delays and frustration for parties involved.
* Lack of resources: The judiciary in Poland often lacks the resources it needs to function effectively, including modern technology and trained staff.

## Rule of law concerns

There are several concerns about the rule of law in Poland, including:

### Capture of the Constitutional Tribunal

The Constitutional Tribunal has been at the center of controversy in recent years, with many critics arguing that it has been captured by the ruling party.

### Undue influence on judges

There have been several cases of undue influence on judges in Poland, including pressure from politicians and other external actors.

### Partisan control of the National Council of the Judiciary

The National Council of the Judiciary has been criticized for being under the control of the ruling party, which has led to concerns about the independence of the judiciary.

#### Arbitrary secondment of judges

There have been several cases of arbitrary secondment of judges in Poland, including the transfer of judges to lower courts or other roles.

### Repercussions in Poland and abroad

The concerns about the rule of law in Poland have had several repercussions, both domestically and internationally. These include:

* Criticism from the European Union: The European Union has criticized Poland for its handling of the judiciary, and has launched several proceedings against the country.
* Protests: There have been several protests in Poland against the government's handling of the judiciary.
* Loss of international credibility: Poland's reputation as a country that respects the rule of law has been damaged.

# See also

* Constitution of Poland
* Government of Poland
* Politics of Poland
* Law of Poland

# Notes

This article has been written in a neutral, encyclopedic tone, and has been based on publicly available information.

2022–23 Figure Skating Season

The 2022–23 figure skating season began on July 1, 2022, and will end on June 30, 2023. During this season, elite skaters will compete on the international stage at the ISU Championships, including the World Figure Skating Championships, Four Continents Figure Skating Championships, and European Figure Skating Championships. Additionally, skaters will participate in the ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating series, the ISU Challenger Series, and other international competitions.

# Season Notes

## Age Eligibility

To be eligible to compete in junior events, skaters must be at least 13 years old but not yet 19 years old (or 21 years old for men's singles) as of July 1, 2022. To be eligible to compete in senior events, skaters must be at least 15 years old (or 16 years old for men's singles) as of July 1, 2022.

## Death of Dmytro Sharpar

On January 2, 2023, Ukrainian figure skater Dmytro Sharpar passed away at the age of 34. Sharpar was a two-time Ukrainian national champion and competed at several international events, including the World Figure Skating Championships and the European Figure Skating Championships.

# Changes

## Partnership Changes

Several pairs and ice dance teams announced changes to their partnerships during the off-season. Some notable changes include:

* Russian pair skaters Anastasia Mishina and Aleksandr Galliamov announced that they would be parting ways due to injury. Mishina will skate with new partner Dmitry Kuznetsov, while Galliamov will skate with new partner Vera Bazarova.
* American ice dance team Madison Hubbell and Zachary Donohue announced that they would be retiring from competitive skating. Hubbell will skate with new partner Jean-Luc Baker.

## Retirements

Several skaters announced their retirement from competitive figure skating during the off-season. Some notable retirements include:

* Canadian pair skaters Meagan Duhamel and Eric Radford announced that they would be retiring from competitive skating. Duhamel and Radford are two-time world champions and three-time Olympic medalists.
* Japanese figure skater Satoko Miyahara announced that she would be retiring from competitive skating. Miyahara is a two-time world medalist and two-time Grand Prix Final champion.

## Coaching Changes

Several skaters announced changes to their coaching teams during the off-season. Some notable changes include:

* Russian figure skater Alexandra Trusova announced that she would be leaving her longtime coach Eteri Tutberidze to skate with new coach Svetlana Sokolovskaya.
* American figure skater Nathan Chen announced that he would be leaving his longtime coach Rafael Arutyunyan to skate with new coach Marina Zueva.

## Nationality Changes

Several skaters announced changes to their nationality during the off-season. Some notable changes include:

* Russian figure skater Alena Kostornaia announced that she would be representing Azerbaijan in competition. Kostornaia is a two-time European champion and two-time Grand Prix Final champion.
* Chinese pair skaters Wenjing Sui and Cong Han announced that they would be representing the United States in competition. Sui and Han are two-time world champions and two-time Olympic medalists.

# International Competitions

## Cancelled Events

Due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, several international competitions were cancelled or postponed during the 2022-23 season. Some notable cancellations include:

* The 2023 World Junior Figure Skating Championships were cancelled due to the ongoing pandemic.
* The 2023 European Figure Skating Championships were postponed until 2024 due to the ongoing pandemic.

Christian Atsu Twasam
=====================

Christian Atsu Twasam was a Ghanaian professional footballer who played as a winger or an attacking midfielder. Atsu began his youth career at the Feyenoord Academy in Ghana, before joining the Portuguese club Porto in 2009. He went on to play for several clubs, including Chelsea, Newcastle United, and Hatayspor, before his untimely death in 2023.

Early Life
-----------

Christian Atsu was born on January 10, 1992, in Ada Foah, Ghana. Growing up in a poor family, Atsu's love for football was evident from an early age. He began playing football in his neighborhood with his friends, using makeshift balls made of rags and plastic bags. Atsu's talents were soon discovered by the Feyenoord Academy in Ghana, a youth development program affiliated with the Dutch club Feyenoord. He joined the academy in 2005 and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming one of the most promising young players in Ghana.

Club Career
------------

### Porto

In 2009, Atsu joined the Portuguese club Porto, signing a five-year contract. He began playing for the club's youth team, before being promoted to the senior team in 2011. Atsu made his professional debut for Porto in 2011, coming on as a substitute in a league match against Olhanense. He scored his first goal for the club in 2012, in a 3-1 win over Nacional. During his time at Porto, Atsu won several titles, including two Primeira Liga championships and the 2011 UEFA Europa League.

### Chelsea

In 2013, Atsu joined the English club Chelsea, signing a five-year contract worth £3.5 million. However, he struggled to establish himself in the first team, making only a handful of appearances in his first season. Atsu was loaned out to several clubs in an attempt to gain more playing experience.

#### Loan to Vitesse

In 2013, Atsu was loaned out to the Dutch club Vitesse for the 2013-2014 season. He made 28 appearances for the club, scoring 5 goals and providing 6 assists. Atsu's performances at Vitesse earned him a call-up to the Ghanaian national team.

#### Loan to Everton

In 2014, Atsu was loaned out to the English club Everton for the 2014-2015 season. He made 5 appearances for the club, scoring 0 goals and providing 0 assists. Atsu's loan spell at Everton was cut short due to a lack of playing time.

#### Loan to Bournemouth

In 2015, Atsu was loaned out to the English club Bournemouth for the 2015-2016 season. He made 2 appearances for the club, scoring 0 goals and providing 0 assists. Atsu's loan spell at Bournemouth was cut short due to a lack of playing time.

#### Loan to Málaga

In 2016, Atsu was loaned out to the Spanish club Málaga for the 2016-2017 season. He made 12 appearances for the club, scoring 2 goals and providing 2 assists. Atsu's performances at Málaga earned him a permanent transfer to Newcastle United.

### Newcastle United

In 2017, Atsu joined the English club Newcastle United, signing a four-year contract worth £6.2 million. He made his debut for the club in 2017, coming on as a substitute in a league match against Tottenham Hotspur. Atsu scored his first goal for the club in 2017, in a 1-0 win over Stoke City. During his time at Newcastle United, Atsu made 107 appearances, scoring 7 goals and providing 10 assists.

### Al-Raed

In 2021, Atsu joined the Saudi Arabian club Al-Raed, signing a two-year contract. He made his debut for the club in 2021, coming on as a substitute in a league match against Al-Hilal. Atsu scored his first goal for the club in 2021, in a 2-1 win over Al-Fayha.

### Hatayspor

In 2022, Atsu joined the Turkish club Hatayspor, signing a one-year contract. He made his debut for the club in 2022, coming on as a substitute in a league match against Kasımpaşa. Atsu scored his first goal for the club in 2022, in a 1-0 win over Antalyaspor.

International Career
--------------------

Atsu made his international debut for Ghana in 2012, coming on as a substitute in a friendly match against Lesotho. He scored his first goal for the national team in 2013, in a 2-0 win over Sudan. Atsu went on to earn 65 caps for Ghana, scoring 10 goals and providing 11 assists. He represented the national team at several international tournaments, including the 2014 FIFA World Cup and the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations.

Personal Life
-------------

Atsu was married to his wife, Marie-Claire Rupio. The couple had two children together. Atsu was known for his charitable work, particularly in his hometown of Ada Foah. He founded the Christian Atsu Foundation, which aimed to provide educational and healthcare support to underprivileged children in Ghana.

Death and Funeral
-----------------

Atsu died on February 6, 2023, at the age of 31, after being trapped under the rubble of his apartment building in Antakya, Turkey, following the 2023 Turkey-Syria earthquake. His body was later recovered and repatriated to Ghana for burial. Atsu's funeral was held on March 17, 2023, at the Accra Sports Stadium in Ghana. He was laid to rest at the Ada Foah cemetery in his hometown.

article:
Anne Heche

Anne Heche (May 25, 1969 - August 14, 2022) was an American actress, director, and screenwriter. Her career spanned over three decades, during which she appeared in numerous films, television shows, and stage productions. Heche was known for her versatility and range, taking on a wide variety of roles in various genres.

#Early life

Anne Heche was born on May 25, 1969, in Aurora, Ohio, to Nancy Heche and Donald Joseph Heche. Her father was a choir director and a Baptist minister, while her mother was a nurse. Heche was the youngest of five children, and her family moved frequently during her childhood due to her father's work. She spent her early years in Ohio, New Jersey, and Illinois before settling in New Orleans, Louisiana.

Heche's early life was marked by tragedy when her father died of AIDS in 1983. Her mother struggled to care for the family, and Heche began working at a young age to support herself. She attended the Francis W. Parker School in Chicago and later moved to New York City to pursue a career in acting.

#Career

##1987–1996: Early television and film roles

Heche began her acting career in the late 1980s, landing small roles on television shows such as "As the World Turns" and "Another World." She made her film debut in the 1993 film "An Ambush of Ghosts," followed by roles in "I'll Do Anything" (1994) and "Wild Side" (1995).

Heche's breakthrough role came in 1996 when she played the dual role of twins Vicky Hudson and Marley Love on the NBC soap opera "Another World." Her performance earned her a Daytime Emmy Award nomination and recognition within the industry.

##1997–1999: Career breakthrough

Heche's career gained momentum in the late 1990s with roles in several high-profile films. She appeared in "Donnie Brasco" (1997) alongside Johnny Depp and Al Pacino, followed by "Wag the Dog" (1997) and "Six Days, Seven Nights" (1998) opposite Harrison Ford.

Heche's performance in "Return to Paradise" (1998) earned her a nomination for the Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Female. Her portrayal of a lawyer who falls in love with a woman in prison, played by Thandie Newton, in the 1998 film "Girls in Prison" also received critical acclaim.

##1998–2001: Directing projects

In addition to her acting career, Heche began exploring her passion for directing in the late 1990s. She made her directorial debut with the 1998 short film "Stripping for Jesus," followed by the 2000 television film "On the Edge."

Heche's directorial work continued with the 2001 television film "If These Walls Could Talk 2," which explored the lives of three lesbian couples in different decades. The film earned her a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Directing for a Miniseries or a Movie.

##2000–2009: Independent films, TV series, and Broadway roles

Heche continued to appear in a wide range of films and television shows throughout the 2000s. She played the lead role in the 2000 film "Prozac Nation," based on the memoir by Elizabeth Wurtzel, and appeared in the 2002 film "John Q" alongside Denzel Washington.

Heche's television work during this period included roles in the series "Everwood" (2004-2005) and "Men in Trees" (2006-2008). She made her Broadway debut in the 2004 play "Twentieth Century," earning a Tony Award nomination for Best Actress in a Play.

##2010–2022: Later acting career

Heche's acting career continued to thrive in the 2010s with roles in films such as "The Vanishing of Sidney Hall" (2017) and "My Friend Dahmer" (2017). She appeared in the 2017 television series "Aftermath" and played the lead role in the 2019 film "Best of Enemies."

Heche's later work also included roles in the television series "Chicago P.D." (2020) and "All Rise" (2021). Her final film appearance was in the 2022 film "Girl in Room 13," a Lifetime movie based on a true story.

#Other media

In addition to her acting and directing career, Heche was also a published author. Her memoir, "Call Me Crazy," was released in 2001 and became a bestseller. The book detailed her struggles with mental health and her experiences with love and loss.

Heche was also a podcaster and hosted the 2020 podcast "Better Together with Anne and Heather," which she co-hosted with her friend Heather Duffy.

#Personal life

##Family

Heche's family life was marked by tragedy and loss. Her father, Donald Joseph Heche, died of AIDS in 1983, and her brother, Nathan Heche, died in a car accident in 1983. Her sister, Susan Heche, died of brain cancer in 2006.

##Relationships

Heche was in a long-term relationship with Ellen DeGeneres from 1997 to 2000. The couple's relationship was highly publicized, and they were considered one of Hollywood's most prominent same-sex couples.

Heche later married Coley Laffoon, a cameraman, in 2001, and the couple had a son, Homer, in 2002. They divorced in 2009. Heche also had a son, Atlas, with her partner James Tupper in 2009.

##Mental health issues

Heche struggled with mental health issues throughout her life, including depression and anxiety. She was hospitalized in 2000 after a breakdown and later spoke publicly about her struggles with mental health.

##Allegations against Harvey Weinstein

In 2017, Heche was one of several women who accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual harassment and misconduct. She alleged that Weinstein had made unwanted advances towards her during the filming of "Six Days, Seven Nights" in 1997.

#Death

##Car crash

On August 5, 2022, Heche was involved in a car crash in the Mar Vista neighborhood of Los Angeles. She was driving a Mini Cooper when she crashed into a house, causing a fire. Heche was extracted from the vehicle and taken to a hospital.

##Hospitalization and death

Heche was hospitalized at the Grossman Burn Center at West Hills Hospital and Medical Center, where she was listed in critical condition. She suffered severe burns and a severe brain injury.

On August 11, 2022, Heche's representatives announced that she had been declared brain dead and was being kept on life support while her family explored options for organ donation.

Heche was officially declared dead on August 14, 2022, at the age of 53.

##Estate

Heche's estate was worth an estimated $4 million at the time of her death. She left behind two sons, Homer and Atlas, who will inherit her estate.

article:
2023 Chinese Balloon Incident

The 2023 Chinese Balloon Incident refers to the detection and downing of a high-altitude reconnaissance balloon of Chinese origin that flew over sensitive U.S. military sites in February 2023. The incident has sparked tensions between the United States and China, with both countries offering differing accounts of the balloon's purpose and intentions.

# Background

## History and Development of Reconnaissance Balloons

Reconnaissance balloons, also known as surveillance balloons or spy balloons, have been used for military and intelligence purposes since the mid-20th century. These balloons typically operate at high altitudes, using cameras and sensors to gather information about enemy territories, troop movements, and military installations. The use of balloons for reconnaissance purposes has been largely replaced by satellite imaging and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), but some countries continue to employ balloons due to their lower operating costs and ability to evade detection.

### Past Chinese Balloons and Unidentified Objects

There have been several reported instances of Chinese balloons and unidentified objects entering U.S. airspace in recent years. In 2020, a Chinese high-altitude balloon was spotted over Hawaii, and in 2022, a Chinese reconnaissance balloon was detected over Alaska. In both cases, the U.S. military monitored the balloons but did not take action to intercept or down them.

## U.S.–China Tensions

Tensions between the United States and China have been escalating in recent years, driven by a range of issues including trade, security, and human rights. The two countries have competing interests in the Asia-Pacific region, and the U.S. has been increasingly critical of China's military expansion and aggressive behavior in the South China Sea. The downing of the Chinese balloon has further strained relations between the two countries, with the U.S. accusing China of violating its sovereignty and China denying any wrongdoing.

# Incident

## Balloon

The balloon in question was a high-altitude reconnaissance balloon, estimated to be around 200 feet (60 meters) tall and weighing several thousand pounds. The balloon was equipped with a propulsion system, allowing it to navigate and change altitude, and carried a payload of sensors and cameras.

### Size, Propulsion, and Payload

The exact specifications of the balloon are not publicly known, but experts have estimated its size and capabilities based on images and witness accounts. The balloon's propulsion system likely used a combination of solar panels and batteries to power its movements. The payload is believed to have included high-resolution cameras, sensors, and communication equipment.

### Signals Intelligence Capabilities

The balloon's signals intelligence capabilities are not publicly known, but experts speculate that it may have been equipped with equipment to intercept and analyze communication signals. This could have included radio frequency (RF) interceptors, cell phone interceptors, or other types of signals intelligence gear.

## Detection

The balloon was first detected by the U.S. military on January 28, 2023, when it entered Alaskan airspace. The U.S. Northern Command (NORTHCOM) and the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) were alerted, and the balloon was tracked as it moved over Canada and into the contiguous United States.

## Flight Path

The balloon's flight path took it over several sensitive U.S. military sites, including Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana and F.E. Warren Air Force Base in Wyoming. The balloon also flew over several major cities, including Seattle, Washington, and Chicago, Illinois.

## U.S. Monitoring and Counterintelligence

The U.S. military monitored the balloon's movements closely, using a combination of radar, satellites, and fighter jets to track its progress. The U.S. also took steps to protect its sensitive military sites, including increasing security measures and restricting access to classified information.

## Downing

article:
Morocco National Football Team

The Morocco national football team represents Morocco in international football competitions and is controlled by the Royal Moroccan Football Federation. The team has a rich history, having participated in numerous international tournaments, including the FIFA World Cup and the Africa Cup of Nations. With a strong following and a talented pool of players, the Moroccan national team is one of the most successful and beloved teams in African football.

# History

## Pre-independence period

The history of football in Morocco dates back to the early 20th century, when the country was under French protectorate. The first football clubs were established in the 1920s, and the sport quickly gained popularity among the Moroccan population. In 1928, the Royal Moroccan Football Federation was founded, and the first national team was formed.

## Beginning of Morocco (1955–1963)

After Morocco gained independence in 1956, the national team began to participate in international competitions. The team's first match was against Iraq in 1957, which ended in a 3-3 draw. In the early 1960s, Morocco participated in several friendly matches against teams from North Africa and the Middle East.

## First appearances in international competitions (1963–1976)

Morocco's first appearance in a major international competition was in the 1964 African Cup of Nations, where the team finished third. In the 1970s, Morocco participated in several international tournaments, including the 1970 FIFA World Cup qualifiers and the 1972 African Cup of Nations.

## Between successes and defeats (1976–1986)

In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Morocco experienced a period of fluctuating success. The team qualified for the 1976 African Cup of Nations, where they finished second, but failed to qualify for the 1982 FIFA World Cup. In 1984, Morocco won the African Cup Winners' Cup, defeating Nigeria 1-0 in the final.

## Golden generation (1986–2000)

The late 1980s and 1990s are considered the golden years of Moroccan football. The team qualified for the 1986 FIFA World Cup, where they reached the round of 16, where they lost to West Germany. In the 1990s, Morocco won the 1991 African Cup of Nations, defeating Algeria 3-1 in the final. The team also qualified for the 1994 and 1998 FIFA World Cups.

## Difficult years (2006–2017)

In the 2000s and 2010s, Morocco experienced a decline in success. The team failed to qualify for the 2006 and 2010 FIFA World Cups and was eliminated in the group stage of the 2013 and 2015 African Cup of Nations.

## Second golden generation (2017–present)

In 2017, Morocco appointed Hervé Renard as the team's head coach, marking the beginning of a new era in Moroccan football. The team qualified for the 2018 FIFA World Cup, where they were eliminated in the group stage. In 2019, Morocco won the African Nations Championship, defeating Mali 2-0 in the final.

# Home stadium

The Morocco national team plays its home matches at the Stade Mohammed V in Casablanca, which has a capacity of 67,000 spectators. The stadium has hosted numerous international matches, including the 1988 African Cup of Nations final.

# Kit suppliers

The Morocco national team's kit supplier is Puma, who have been the team's official kit supplier since 2015.

# Results and fixtures

## 2023

article:
Christopher (film)

Christopher is a 2023 Indian Malayalam-language action thriller film written and directed by B. Unnikrishnan. The film stars Mammootty in the title role, alongside Aishwarya Lekshmi, Sneha, and Amala Paul in key roles. The movie follows the story of a retired police officer who is forced to return to his duties to solve a mystery surrounding his daughter's death.

#Plot

The film begins with Christopher (Mammootty), a retired police officer who is living a peaceful life with his family. However, his life takes a drastic turn when his daughter, Ancy (Aishwarya Lekshmi), a journalist, is found dead under mysterious circumstances. The police investigation reveals that Ancy was investigating a high-profile case before her death, and her murder is linked to the case. Christopher is forced to return to his duties to solve the mystery surrounding his daughter's death.

As Christopher delves deeper into the case, he discovers a web of corruption and deceit that goes all the way to the top. He faces resistance from his colleagues and superiors, who are either corrupt or incompetent. Despite the odds, Christopher is determined to uncover the truth and bring justice to his daughter.

Throughout the film, Christopher's character is shown to be a complex and nuanced one. He is a man who is driven by his sense of justice and his love for his family. However, he is also a man who is willing to bend the rules and take risks to achieve his goals.

The film's plot is full of twists and turns, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. The movie's climax is particularly noteworthy, with Christopher facing off against the main antagonist in a thrilling showdown.

#Cast

* Mammootty as Christopher
* Aishwarya Lekshmi as Ancy

* Aditi Ravi as Nimitha

#Production

The film was produced by B. Unnikrishnan under the banner of RD Illuminations. The movie was shot in various locations in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. The film's cinematography was handled by Faiz Siddik, while the editing was done by Shameer Muhammed.

The film's music was composed by Justin Varghese, with lyrics by Jis Joy. The movie's soundtrack features several popular songs, including the hit single "Kannil Pettum".

The film's production was marked by several challenges, including delays and changes in the cast and crew. However, the film's director, B. Unnikrishnan, has stated that he is pleased with the final product and believes that it will be a commercial success.

#Release

The film was released on February 9, 2023, in theaters across Kerala and other parts of India. The movie received a mixed response from audiences and critics, with some praising its action sequences and others criticizing its storyline.

The film's release was also marked by controversy, with some critics accusing the film of promoting vigilantism and violence. However, the film's director has denied these allegations, stating that the film is a work of fiction and not meant to be taken literally.

#Reception

##Critical response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its action sequences and others criticizing its storyline. The film's lead actor, Mammootty, received praise for his performance, with many critics noting that he brings gravity and depth to the film.

However, the film's storyline and direction were criticized by some critics, who noted that the film's pacing is uneven and the plot is predictable. The film's music and cinematography were also praised by some critics, who noted that they add to the film's overall atmosphere and tension.

Overall, the film's critical response was mixed, with some critics praising its action sequences and others criticizing its storyline.

article:
Orphan Wells in Alberta, Canada

Introduction

Orphan wells in Alberta, Canada, refer to abandoned oil and gas wells that no longer have a responsible owner or operator to manage and reclaim them. These wells pose significant environmental and financial risks to the province, landowners, and municipalities. This article provides an overview of the current situation, context, and responses to the issue of orphan wells in Alberta.

# Current Overview

As of 2022, there are over 170,000 inactive oil and gas wells in Alberta, with approximately 97,000 of them considered "orphaned." These wells are no longer producing and have been abandoned by their owners, often due to bankruptcy or financial insolvency. The number of orphan wells continues to grow, with an estimated 200-300 wells being added to the list each year.

# Context

The oil and gas industry has been a significant contributor to Alberta's economy for decades. However, the decline of conventional oil and gas reserves, combined with low energy prices and increasing environmental regulations, has led to a surge in bankruptcies and abandoned wells. Many companies have gone out of business, leaving behind a legacy of orphaned wells that require costly reclamation and remediation.

# Landowners and Municipalities

Landowners and municipalities are often left to deal with the consequences of orphan wells. These wells can be a source of contamination, posing risks to soil, water, and air quality. Landowners may be unable to use their land for agricultural purposes or other activities due to the presence of orphan wells. Municipalities are also affected, as they may be responsible for providing emergency services and managing the environmental impacts of orphan wells.

# Orphan Well Association

The Orphan Well Association (OWA) is a non-profit organization established in 2002 to manage and reclaim orphan wells in Alberta. The OWA is responsible for identifying and prioritizing orphan wells, as well as conducting reclamation and remediation work. The organization is funded through a combination of federal and provincial subsidies, as well as industry levies.

# OWA Funding

## Federal and Provincial Subsidies

The OWA receives funding from the federal and provincial governments to support its operations. In 2020, the federal government announced a $1.7 billion funding package to support the cleanup of orphan wells in Alberta, Saskatchewan, and British Columbia. The provincial government has also provided funding to support the OWA's work.

# Alberta Energy Regulator

The Alberta Energy Regulator (AER) is responsible for regulating the oil and gas industry in Alberta. The AER has implemented various measures to address the issue of orphan wells, including requiring companies to provide financial security for well reclamation and remediation. However, some critics argue that the AER's regulations do not go far enough to prevent the creation of new orphan wells.

# Legal and Regulatory Considerations

## Polluter Pays Principle

The polluter pays principle is a fundamental concept in environmental law, which holds that those responsible for environmental damage should bear the costs of cleanup and remediation. In the case of orphan wells, the polluter pays principle is often compromised, as the responsible parties may have gone out of business or be unable to pay for reclamation and remediation.

## Suspended Inactive Wells

Suspended inactive wells are wells that are not currently producing but have not been officially abandoned. These wells can pose environmental risks, as they may not be properly maintained or monitored. The AER has implemented regulations to require companies to regularly inspect and maintain suspended inactive wells.

# Bankruptcies and Orphan Wells

## Strategic Packaging of Costly Liabilities with Productive Assets

In some cases, companies have been accused of strategically packaging costly liabilities, such as orphan wells, with productive assets in order to avoid responsibility for reclamation and remediation. This practice can make it difficult for regulators to hold companies accountable for their environmental obligations.

# Environmental Impacts of Orphan Wells

## Fugitive Gas Emissions

Orphan wells can be a source of fugitive gas emissions, which contribute to climate change. A study by the Pembina Institute found that orphan wells in Alberta are releasing an estimated 7.5 million metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year.

## Surface Casing Vent Flow (SCVF) and Gas Migration (GM)

Surface casing vent flow (SCVF) and gas migration (GM) are two types of environmental hazards associated with orphan wells. SCVF occurs when gas escapes from the wellbore and vents to the surface, while GM occurs when gas migrates through the soil and rock formations. Both SCVF and GM can pose risks to soil, water, and air quality.

# Potential Geothermal Conversion of Orphan Wells in Alberta

Some researchers have suggested that orphan wells in Alberta could be converted for geothermal energy production. This would involve repurposing the wells to generate heat or electricity from underground reservoirs. While this idea is still in its infancy, it could potentially provide a new use for orphan wells and reduce their environmental impacts.

# Responses

The issue of orphan wells in Alberta requires a coordinated response from government, industry, and civil society. Some potential responses include:

* Increasing funding for the OWA to support reclamation and remediation efforts
* Implementing stronger regulations to prevent the creation of new orphan wells
* Encouraging industry to adopt best practices for well abandonment and reclamation
* Supporting research and development of new technologies to convert orphan wells for geothermal energy production

# See Also

* List of oil and gas companies in Alberta
* Environmental impact of the oil and gas industry
* Geothermal energy in Canada

# Notes

This article is a general overview of the issue of orphan wells in Alberta, Canada. It is not intended to be a comprehensive or definitive treatment of the subject.

# External Links

* Orphan Well Association
* Alberta Energy Regulator
* Pembina Institute

article:
2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup

The 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup was the eighth edition of the ICC Men's T20 World Cup, a biennial international Twenty20 cricket tournament contested by national teams affiliated with the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament was hosted by Australia in October and November 2022.

# Background

The 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup was originally scheduled to take place in India in 2021, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) was unable to host the tournament. As a result, the ICC announced that the 2021 tournament would be hosted by the United Arab Emirates and Oman instead. The 2022 tournament was then awarded to Australia.

# Teams and qualifications

A total of 16 teams participated in the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup. The top 12 teams from the 2021 ICC Men's T20 World Cup automatically qualified for the 2022 tournament. The remaining four teams were determined through the Global Qualifiers.

## Global Qualifiers

The Global Qualifiers were held in two phases. The first phase consisted of two groups of eight teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the second phase. The second phase consisted of two groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group qualifying for the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup.

# Match officials

The match officials for the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup were announced by the ICC in September 2022. The officials included 16 umpires and four match referees.

# Squads

Each team was required to submit a squad of 15 players for the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup. The squads were announced by the teams in September and October 2022.

# Venues

The 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup was hosted by Australia, with matches played at seven venues across the country. The venues were:

* Adelaide Oval in Adelaide
* Brisbane Cricket Ground in Brisbane
* Melbourne Cricket Ground in Melbourne
* Perth Stadium in Perth
* Sydney Cricket Ground in Sydney
* Hobart's Bellerive Oval in Hobart
* Geelong's Kardinia Park in Geelong

# Prize money

The total prize money for the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup was US$5.6 million. The winning team received US$1.6 million, while the runner-up team received US$800,000.

# Warm-up matches

A series of warm-up matches were played between the participating teams before the start of the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup. The warm-up matches were played from October 10 to October 13, 2022.

# First round

The first round of the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup consisted of two groups of four teams each. The top two teams from each group advanced to the Super 12.

## Group A

Group A consisted of Sri Lanka, Namibia, United Arab Emirates, and Netherlands. Sri Lanka and Netherlands advanced to the Super 12.

## Group B

Group B consisted of West Indies, Scotland, Zimbabwe, and Ireland. West Indies and Zimbabwe advanced to the Super 12.

# Super 12

The Super 12 consisted of two groups of six teams each. The top two teams from each group advanced to the knockout stage.

## Group 1

Group 1 consisted of Australia, Afghanistan, England, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, and Ireland. England and Australia advanced to the knockout stage.

## Group 2

Group 2 consisted of India, Pakistan, South Africa, Bangladesh, Zimbabwe, and Netherlands. India and Pakistan advanced to the knockout stage.

# Knockout stage

The knockout stage consisted of two semi-finals and the final.

## Semi-finals

The first semi-final was played between England and India at the Adelaide Oval, with England winning by 10 wickets. The second semi-final was played between Pakistan and Australia at the Sydney Cricket Ground, with Pakistan winning by 5 wickets.

## Final

The final was played between England and Pakistan at the Melbourne Cricket Ground, with England winning by 5 wickets.

# Statistics

## Most runs

The top run-scorers in the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup were:

* Virat Kohli (India) - 296 runs
* Jos Buttler (England) - 225 runs
* Suryakumar Yadav (India) - 217 runs

## Most wickets

The top wicket-takers in the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup were:

* Wanindu Hasaranga (Sri Lanka) - 15 wickets
* Adil Rashid (England) - 12 wickets
* Shadab Khan (Pakistan) - 11 wickets

# Team of the tournament

The team of the tournament was announced by the ICC after the conclusion of the 2022 ICC Men's T20 World Cup. The team consisted of:

* Jos Buttler (England) - wicket-keeper
* Alex Hales (England) - batsman
* Virat Kohli (India) - batsman

* Shaheen Afridi (Pakistan) - bowler

# Notes

Chapel-le-Dale (valley)

Chapel-le-Dale is a picturesque and historically significant valley located in the Yorkshire Dales National Park, North Yorkshire, England. The valley is nestled in the heart of the Pennines, a mountain range that stretches across northern England. Chapel-le-Dale is known for its stunning natural beauty, rich cultural heritage, and diverse wildlife. The valley has a long and complex history, shaped by the interactions of geology, climate, and human activity.

# History

The history of Chapel-le-Dale is deeply intertwined with the development of the surrounding region. The valley has been inhabited since prehistoric times, with evidence of ancient settlements and burial sites found throughout the area.

## River names

The valley is drained by the River Doe, which flows into the River Lune. The 2022–23 NHL transactions list is a compilation of all the transactions that occurred during the 2022–23 National Hockey League (NHL) season. This list includes player signings, trades, contract terminations, and retirements.

# Retirement

article:
Nagpuria People

The Nagpuria people are an Indo-Aryan ethnic group native to the Nagpur region in the eastern part of India. They have a distinct cultural identity shaped by their history, language, and traditions. This article provides an overview of the Nagpuria people, including their names, history, communities, culture, and notable individuals.

# Names

The term "Nagpuria" is derived from the name of the city of Nagpur, which is the largest city in the Vidarbha region of Maharashtra, India. The people of this region have been referred to by various names throughout history, including Nagpurkar, Nagpuri, and Vidarbha. However, the term "Nagpuria" is the most commonly used and accepted name for this ethnic group.

# History

## Prehistoric era

The Nagpur region has been inhabited since prehistoric times. Archaeological evidence suggests that the region was home to various ancient civilizations, including the Mesolithic and Neolithic cultures. The discovery of stone tools, pottery, and other artifacts in the region provides evidence of human habitation dating back to the Stone Age.

## Ancient period

The Nagpur region was an important center of trade and commerce during the ancient period. The region was part of the Mauryan Empire, which was one of the largest empires in ancient India. The Mauryans built several roads, bridges, and other infrastructure in the region, which facilitated trade and communication with other parts of the empire.

## Medieval period

During the medieval period, the Nagpur region was ruled by various dynasties, including the Vakataka, Chalukya, and Yadava dynasties. The region was an important center of learning and culture, with several universities and centers of learning established during this period. The famous Vidarbha Mahasabha, a gathering of scholars and intellectuals, was held in the region during this period.

## Modern period

During the modern period, the Nagpur region was ruled by the Bhonsle dynasty, which established the Nagpur Kingdom in the 18th century. The kingdom was later annexed by the British East India Company, and the region became part of the British Raj. The Nagpur region played an important role in the Indian independence movement, with several prominent leaders, including Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru, visiting the region to mobilize support for the movement.

## Post Independence

article:
2023 United States Banking Crisis

The 2023 United States banking crisis refers to a series of events that led to the collapse of several major banks in the United States, beginning in March 2023. The crisis was sparked by a combination of factors, including rising interest rates, increased regulatory scrutiny, and concerns about the stability of the banking system.

# Background
The banking crisis was preceded by a period of rapid growth in the US banking sector, fueled by low interest rates and a strong economy. However, as the Federal Reserve began to raise interest rates in 2022 to combat inflation, many banks found themselves facing increasing pressure on their balance sheets. Additionally, the collapse of the cryptocurrency market in 2022 led to a decline in deposits at some banks, further exacerbating the situation.

# Liquidation of Silvergate Bank
## Background
Silvergate Bank was a California-based bank that specialized in serving the cryptocurrency industry. The bank had grown rapidly in recent years, but its business model was heavily dependent on the cryptocurrency market.

## Events
On March 8, 2023, Silvergate Bank announced that it would be winding down its operations and liquidating its assets. The bank cited the decline in the cryptocurrency market and the resulting decline in deposits as the reason for its decision. The liquidation of Silvergate Bank was seen as a significant event in the banking industry, as it was the first major bank to fail in 2023.

# Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank
## Background
Silicon Valley Bank was a California-based bank that specialized in serving the technology industry. The bank had grown rapidly in recent years, but its business model was heavily dependent on the tech industry.

## Events
On March 10, 2023, Silicon Valley Bank announced that it would be seeking additional capital to shore up its balance sheet. However, the bank's efforts to raise capital were unsuccessful, and on March 17, 2023, the bank was taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC). The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank was seen as a major event in the banking industry, as it was the largest bank to fail in the US since the 2008 financial crisis.

# Collapse of Signature Bank
## Background
Signature Bank was a New York-based bank that specialized in serving the cryptocurrency industry. The bank had grown rapidly in recent years, but its business model was heavily dependent on the cryptocurrency market.

## Events
On March 12, 2023, Signature Bank announced that it would be taken over by the FDIC. The bank's collapse was seen as a significant event in the banking industry, as it was the second major bank to fail in 2023.

# Collapse of First Republic Bank
## Background
First Republic Bank was a California-based bank that specialized in serving the wealthy. The bank had grown rapidly in recent years, but its business model was heavily dependent on the wealthy.

## Events
On April 1, 2023, First Republic Bank announced that it would be taken over by JPMorgan Chase. The bank's collapse was seen as a significant event in the banking industry, as it was the fourth major bank to fail in 2023.

# Aftermath
The collapse of the four major banks in 2023 had significant repercussions for the US banking industry. The events led to a decline in confidence in the banking system, and many banks faced increased pressure on their balance sheets.

## Bank Term Funding Program
In response to the crisis, the Federal Reserve announced the creation of the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP). The program provided loans to banks for up to one year, collateralized by a wide range of assets. The BTFP was seen as a significant development, as it provided a lifeline to banks facing liquidity pressures.

## Government discussion of other funding
In addition to the BTFP, the US government discussed other measures to provide funding to banks. These measures included the creation of a new bank deposit insurance fund and the provision of additional capital to banks.

## U.S. investigations
The collapse of the four major banks in 2023 led to a number of investigations by US regulatory agencies. These investigations focused on the causes of the collapse and the role of regulatory failures.

## Economic impact
The collapse of the four major banks in 2023 had significant economic implications. The events led to a decline in confidence in the banking system, and many businesses faced increased difficulty in accessing credit.

## International impact
The collapse of the four major banks in 2023 also had significant international implications. The events led to a decline in confidence in the global banking system, and many countries faced increased pressure on their banking systems.
